projects.name: Coorong Project

developer.name: Odonata
developer.description: Odonata is a not-for-profit entity supporting biodiversity impact solutions.

steward.name: Ngarrindjeri Tribe
steward.description: The Ngarrindjeri culture is centered around the lower lakes of the Murray River.

projects.shortDescription: This project is restoring and conserving a large area of native grassland in Southern Australia.
projects.longDescription:
The project will see up to 1.3M Biodiversity Offset Units become available via formal accreditation with the South Australian Department of Environment and Water. The unique site comprises a pristine example of shrub and woodlands associated with the RAMSAR recognised Coorong Region, of particular cultural and environmental significance. A comprehensive site management plan will be undertaken in partnership with local indigenous land owners with the ownership of this and eventually passed on to these groups.

This project represents a truly unique offsetting opportunity, in proximity to Adelaide and in a vitally important bioregion.

This property is a rare pocket of wetlands and woodlands located near the township of Menindee South Australia, nestled in between the Coorong national park and Lake Albert.

As one of the few remaining sections of privately owned remnant vegetation in the area, this represents a unique opportunity for long term preservation. The Coorong, Lake Alexandrina and Lake Albert Wetland is an international significant RAMSAR wetland ecosystems at the intersection of the Murray River and Southern Ocean.

This vital habitat comprises a unique mix of both freshwater and saltwater wetlands and coastal woodlands. The Coorong is the heart of the traditional lands of Ngarrindjeri people, who have hunted and camped on the Mt Sandy property for thousands of years.
keyOutcomesActivities: Site accredited as a Specific Environmental Benefit (SEB) site and credits created by the South Australian Department of Environment and Water.
A land management services agreement will be established with a local indigenous group, employing people from the local community.
The site will be managed in accordance with an agreed management plan to reduce weed pressure, improve the biodiversity value of the location and preserve the value of the land in perpetuity.

After 10 years the land will be vetted to Rigney Namawi Pty Ltd (local indigenous traditional owners). Six monthly project updates in the form of videos, blog posts and photographs will be produced for the first 5 years of the project.

landManagementActions.name: Reduce pest populations
landManagementActions.description: Monitor and reduce the population of foxes, cats, dingos/wild dogs.

landManagementActions.name: Prevent any new weeds or pests becoming established
landManagementActions.description: Monitor sites for any new weeds or pests. If observed, plan and implement a control program.

landManagementActions.name: Eradicate populations of declared weeds
landManagementActions.description: Conserving the plant habitats in the area along rivers and streams.

landManagementActions.name: Decommission all artificial water sources
landManagementActions.description: Identify artificial water sources. Prioritise those close to boundaries and decommission by either blocking inflow or excluding stock with fences.

landManagementActions.name: Limit impact from native mammals
landManagementActions.description: Determine the carrying capacity for the property and monitor the population to keep the number below carrying capacity.

landManagementActions.name: Determine impacts for herbivory on native vegetation
landManagementActions.description: Establish a minimum of three fenced exclosures to prevent grazing from herbivores (both native and introduced).

impact.name: Biodiversity
impact.description: Healthy ecosystems and rich biodiversity are fundamental to life on our planet.

impact.name: Soil organic carbon
impact.description: Sequestering carbon in SOC is one way to mitigate climate change.

impact.name: Above ground biomass
impact.description: Increasing all living biomass which is located above the ground.

impact.name: Soil health
impact.description: The capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.

creditClass.name: Australian Biodiversity Units (ABU’s)
creditClass.description:
ABU’s are an Australian Government endorsed biodiversity credit. An individual ABU represents a 1.5m square area of land of significant environmental value that has been placed under a conservation covenant and agreed management plan. The covenant and management plan secure the long term preservation of the site and ensure the biodiversity value is protected in perpetuity. Vegetation types may include forests, grasslands, mallees, saltmarshes, scrubs, shrublands, wetlands, and woodlands. 

ABU’s are an innovative and unique way for organisations to preserve a tangible section of Australia’s unique natural habitat.

projects.name: Andover Farm

developer.name: Wide Open Agriculture
developer.description: Wide Open Agriculture (ASX: WOA) is a Regenerative Food & Farming company.

steward.name: Rob Rex and Carolyn Rex
steward.description: Rob and Carolyn Rex farm and manage this land using the principles of regenerative agriculture.

projects.shortDescription: Andover is a 1787 hectare broadacre cropping and sheep farm near Kojonup in Western Australia’s Wheatbelt.
projects.longDescription:
Andover (1137 Boscabel-Chittinup Road, Boscabel) is a 1787 ha broadacre property producing canola, wheat, barley and sheep. At latitude -33.68065 and longitude 116.97219, it is situated in the Shire of Kojonup on the border of the Shire of West Arthur.

There are three partners involved in the long-term management of Andover. The property is owned by two Dutch investors who require a sign-off on key decisions. It is farmed and managed by Rob and Carolyn Rex in a partnership model operating on the principles of regenerative agriculture and Wide Open Agriculture (WOA) who act as a bridge between the landowners and farmers/land managers.

Additionally, the South West Catchment Council (SWCC) is providing some funding for fencing, revegetation, monitoring and the development of this 5-year revegetation implementation plan through their “Managing Vegetation on Farm Targeting Pollinators and Farm Resilience” project.
keyOutcomesActivities: The Conservation Covenant protects land for 100 years minimum.
The land will be protected and managed to mitigate fire risk.
Weed management will be undertaken for the natural vegetation to flourish.
Will be fenced against feral pests and predators
Threatened species sanctuary (specific to each area)

landManagementActions.name: Four year rotation
landManagementActions.description: The 2019 Crop plan for Andover is based on a 4 year rotational system encompassing a cereal crop – canola crop – cereal crop – legume crop. A good rotation including a legume crop that fixes nitrogen ensures healthier soil and more resistance to pest and disease build up.

landManagementActions.name: Multi species crops
landManagementActions.description: Various multi species crops were planted this season for a mix of soil amelioration and fodder. Multi species crops are even more efficient at improving the health and resilience of the soil to pathogens, and providing a healthy environment for soil biology.

landManagementActions.name: Stock grazing
landManagementActions.description: A mix of rye corn, serradella and sub clover has been planted as a pasture mix for stock grazing. Sheep are currently being grazed in several paddocks along with the low wetland area along the creekline.

landManagementActions.name: Feed mix
landManagementActions.description: A Lupin, pea and canola mix has been planted to be harvested as a multispecies feed mix.

landManagementActions.name: Prevent any new weeds or pests becoming established
landManagementActions.description: Monitor sites for any new weeds or pests. If observed, plan and implement a control program.

landManagementActions.name: Establish wind breaks to protect bushland
landManagementActions.description: Wind breaks placed in the paddocks to the west could protect 10 tree heights down wind.
